episode_title: THE ONE WHERE MR. HECKLES DIES
characters: Originally written by Michael Curtis and Greg Malins Trascribed by Mindy Mattingly Phillips  With Minor Adjustments by
raw_text:
THE ONE WHERE MR. HECKLES DIES
Originally written by Michael Curtis and Greg Malins Trascribed by Mindy Mattingly Phillips  With Minor Adjustments by: Eric Aasen
CHANDLER: Hey.
MONICA: So how was Joan?
CHANDLER: I broke up with her. 
CHANDLER: They were huge. When she sneezed, bats flew out of them.
RACHEL: Come on, they were not that huge.
CHANDLER: I'm tellin' you, she leaned back, I could see her brain.
MONICA: How many perfectly fine women are you gonna reject over the most superficial insignificant things?
JOEY: Hold it hold it. I gotta side with Chandler on this one. When I first moved to the city, I went out a couple of times with this girl, really hot, great kisser, but she had the biggest Adam's apple. It made me nuts.
CHANDLER: You or me?
ROSS: I got it. Uh, Joey, women don't have Adam's apples.
JOEY: You guys are messin' with me, right?
ALL: Yeah.
JOEY: That was a good one. For a second there, I was like, "whoa."
PHOEBE: You name one woman that you broke up with for a real reason.
CHANDLER: Maureen Rosilla.
ROSS: Not hating Yanni is not a real reason.
(knock)
MONICA: Hello, Mr. Heckles.
MR. HECKLES: You're doing it again.
MONICA: We're not doing anything.
MR. HECKLES: You're stomping. It's disturbing my birds.
RACHEL: You don't have birds.
MR. HECKLES: I could have birds.
MONICA: Ok, Mr. Heckles, we'll try to keep it down.
MR. HECKLES: Thank you. I'm going to rejoin my dinner party.
RACHEL: All right, bye-bye.
CHANDLER: Ok, Janice. Janice. You gotta give me Janice. That wasn't about being picky.
ROSS: We'll give you Janice.
PHOEBE: I miss Janice though. "Hello, Chandler Bing."
RACHEL: "Oh, my, god."
JOEY: "Oh, Chandler, now, now, that's it. There, faster!"
MONICA: Stop with the broom, we're not making noise.
RACHEL: We won. We won!
MONICA: Mr. Heckles.
RACHEL: How did this happen?
MR. TREEGER: He musta been sweepin'. They found a broom in his hand.
MONICA: That's terrible.
MR. TREEGER: I know. I was sweepin' yesterday. It coulda been me.ROSS: Sure, sweepin'. You never know.
MR. TREEGER: You never know.
PHOEBE: Ok, it's very faint, but I can still sense him in the building. Go into the light, Mr. Heckles!
CHANDLER: Ok, Phoebe.
PHOEBE: I'm sorry, but sometimes they need help. That's fine. Go ahead and scoff. You know, there're a lot of things that I don't believe in, but that doesn't mean they're not true.
JOEY: Such as?
PHOEBE: Like crop circles, or the Bermuda triangle, or evolution?
ROSS: Whoa, whoa, whoa. What, you don't, uh, you don't believe in evolution?
PHOEBE: Nah. Not really.
ROSS: You don't believe in evolution?
PHOEBE: I don't know, it's just, you know...monkeys, Darwin, you know, it's a, it's a nice story, I just think it's a little too easy.
ROSS: Too easy? Too...The process of every living thing on this planet evolving over millions of years from single-celled organisms, too easy?
PHOEBE: Yeah, I just don't buy it.
ROSS: Uh, excuse me. Evolution is not for you to buy, Phoebe. Evolution is scientific fact, like, like, like the air we breathe, like gravity.
PHOEBE: Ok, don't get me started on gravity.
ROSS: You uh, you don't believe in gravity?
PHOEBE: Well, it's not so much that you know, like I don't believe in it, you know, it's just...I don't know, lately I get the feeling that I'm not so much being pulled down as I am being pushed.
(knock)
CHANDLER: Uh-Oh. It's Isaac Newton, and he's pissed.
MR. TREEGER: There she is. And over there, that's the other one. This is Mr. Buddy Boyle, Mr. Heckles' attorney. He'd like to talk to you.
MONICA: What can we do for you?
MR. BOYLE: All right, kids. Here's the deal. According to my client's will, he wants to leave all his earthly possessions to "the noisy girls in the apartment above mine".
MONICA: Well, what about his family?
MR. BOYLE: He didn't have any.
RACHEL: Ok, so let's talk money.
MR. BOYLE: All right, there was none. Let's talk signing. You be noisy girl number one, you be noisy girl number two.
MONICA: I can't believe that this whole time we thought he hated us. I mean, isn't it amazing how much you can touch someone's life, without even knowing it?...Would you look at this dump? He hated us. This is his final revenge!
RACHEL: Have you ever seen so much crap?
CHANDLER: Actually, I think this apartment sullies the good name of crap
JOEY: Check this out. Can I have this?
ROSS: How can you not believe in evolution?
PHOEBE: Just don't. Look at this funky shirt!
ROSS: Pheebs, I have studied evolution my entire adult life. Ok, I can tell you, we have collected fossils from all over the world that actually show the evolution of different species, ok? You can literally see them evolving through time.
PHOEBE: Really? You can actually see it?
ROSS: You bet. In the U.S., China, Africa, all over.
PHOEBE: See, I didn't know that.
ROSS: Well, there you go.
PHOEBE: Huh. So now, the real question is, who put those fossils there, and why?
CHANDLER: Hey, look at this. "My Big Book of Grievances."
JOEY: Hey, there's me! April 17th. Excessive noise. Italian guy comes homes with a date. Hey Chandler, look, you're in here too.
CHANDLER: April 18th, excessive noise. Italian guy's gay roommate comes home with the dry-cleaning. Well that's excellent.
RACHEL: Monica, Monica, look at this lamp. Is this tacky or what? We have to have this.
MONICA: Rache, I think we have enough regular lamps.
RACHEL: What? Come on, it's not like I'm asking for this girly clock or anything, which, by the way, I also think is very cool.
MONICA: It doesn't go with any of my stuff.
RACHEL: Well, what about my stuff?
MONICA: You don't have any stuff.
RACHEL: You still think of it as your apartment, don't you?
MONICA: No.
RACHEL: Yes you do. You think of it as your apartment, and I'm just somebody who rents a room.
MONICA: Mmmmm.
RACHEL: Ok, while you "mmm" on it for awhile, I'm gonna go find a place for my new lamp.
ROSS: Ok, Pheebs. See how I'm making these little toys move? Opposable thumbs. Without evolution, how do you explain opposable thumbs?
PHOEBE: Maybe the overlords needed them to steer their spacecrafts.
ROSS: Please tell me you're joking.
PHOEBE: Look, can't we just say that you believe in something, and I don't.
ROSS: No, no, Pheebs, we can't, ok, because--
PHOEBE: What is this obsessive need you have to make everyone agree with you? No, what's that all about? I think, I think maybe it's time you put Ross under the microscope.
ROSS: Is there blood coming out of my ears?
JOEY: Check it out, check it out. Heckles' high school yearbook.
CHANDLER: Wow, he looks so normal.
PHOEBE: He's even kind of cute.
JOEY: "Heckles, you crack me up in science class. You're the funniest kid in school.
CHANDLER: Funniest? Heckles? 
JOEY: That's what it says.
CHANDLER: Wow, Heckles was voted class clown, and so was I. He was right. Would you listen to that?
PHOEBE: I'd call that excessive.
CHANDLER: Whoa! 
JOEY: What?
CHANDLER: Heckles played clarinet in band, and I played clarinet. And he was in the scale modeler's club, and I was, well, there was no club, but I sure thought they were cool.
JOEY: So, you were both dorks. Big deal.
CHANDLER: I just think it's weird, you know? Heckles and me, Heckles, and me, me and Heckles...Would you knock it off?
JOEY: Have you been here all night?
CHANDLER: Look at this. Pictures of all the women that Heckles went out with. Look what he wrote on them. Vivian, too tall. Madge, big gums. Too loud, too smart, makes noise when she eats. This is, this is me. This is what I do. I'm gonna end up alone, just like he did.
JOEY: Chandler, Heckles was a nut case.
CHANDLER: Our trains are on the same track, ok? Yeah, sure, I'm coming up 30 years behind him, but the stops are all the same. Bitter Town. Aloneville. Hermit Junction.
JOEY: All right, you know what we gotta do? We gotta get you outta here. Come on, I'll buy you breakfast, let's go.
CHANDLER: What if I never find someone? Or worse, what if I've found her, but I dumped her because she pronounced it "supposably"?
JOEY: Chandler, come on, you're gonna find somebody.
CHANDLER: How do you know that? How?
JOEY: I don't know, I'm just tryin' to help you out.
CHANDLER: You'll see, you guys are all gonna go off and get married, and I'm gonna end up alone. Will you promise me something? When you're married, will you invite me over for holidays?
JOEY: Well, I don't know. I don't know what we're gonna be doin'. I mean, what if we're at her folks' place?
CHANDLER: Yeah, I understand.
JOEY: You can come over and watch the Super Bowl. Every year, all right?
CHANDLER: You know what? I'm not gonna end up like this. I'll see you man.
JOEY: Supposably. Supposably. Did they go to the zoo? Supposably.
CHANDLER: (on phone) Hi, it's me.
JANICE: Oh, my, god.
PHOEBE: Janice? You called Janice?
CHANDLER: Yes, Janice. Why is that so difficult for you to comprehend?
ROSS: You remember Janice, right?
CHANDLER: Yes. She was smart, she was pretty, and she honestly cared about me. Janice is my last chance to have somebody.
JANICE: Helloo!!
CHANDLER: Oh, my, god!
JOEY: Geez, look how fat she got.
JANICE: Hey, it's everybody.
CHANDLER: Janice, you're--
JANICE: Yes, I am.
CHANDLER: Is it--?
JANICE: Is it yours? Ha! You wish, Chandler Bing. You are looking at a married lady now.
CHANDLER: Congratulations.
JANICE: Oh, sweetie, I'm sorry.
CHANDLER: You couldn't have told me about this on the phone?
JANICE: And what? Missed the expression on your face? Janice likes to have her fun.
MONICA: Hey, Rache. You know what we haven't played in a while?
RACHEL: What?
MONICA: Hide the Lamp.
RACHEL: Monica, let it go.
MONICA: Did you know I was allergic to shellfish?
RACHEL: Well, then, you'll just have to eat the other lamps.
PHOEBE: Uh-oh. It's Scary Scientist Man.
ROSS: Ok, Phoebe, this is it. In this briefcase I carry actual scientific facts. A briefcase of facts, if you will. Some of these fossils are over 200 million years old.
PHOEBE: Ok, look, before you even start, I'm not denying evolution, ok, I'm just saying that it's one of the possibilities.
ROSS: It's the only possibility, Phoebe.
PHOEBE: Ok, Ross, could you just open your mind like this much, ok? Wasn't there a time when the brightest minds in the world believed that the world was flat? And, up until like what, 50 years ago, you all thought the atom was the smallest thing, until you split it open, and this like, whole mess of crap came out. Now, are you telling me that you are so unbelievably arrogant that you can't admit that there's a teeny tiny possibility that you could be wrong about this?
ROSS: There might be, a teeny, tiny, possibility.
PHOEBE: I can't believe you caved.
ROSS: What?
PHOEBE: You just abandoned your whole belief system. I mean, before, I didn't agree with you, but at least I respected you. How, how, how are you going to go into work tomorrow? How, how are you going to face the other science guys? How, how are you going to face yourself? Oh! That was fun. So who's hungry?
RACHEL: I am. Let me just get my coat.
MONICA: Ok, all right. It was an accident, I swear, all right. I was putting on my jacket, and the thing, and the lamp, and it broke.
RACHEL: Oh, please, Monica. You've always hated my lamp, and then, all of a sudden, it's just magically broken?
MONICA: Phoebe, tell her!
PHOEBE: Ok, I didn't see it, because I was putting on my jacket, but I uh want to believe you.
RACHEL: Hey Chandler. Monica just broke my seashell lamp.
CHANDLER: Neat. I'm gonna die alone.
RACHEL: Ok, you win.
MONICA: Chandler, you're not gonna die alone.
CHANDLER: Janice was my safety net, ok? And now I have to get a snake.
PHOEBE: Uh huh. Why is that?
CHANDLER: If I'm gonna be an old, lonely man, I'm gonna need a thing, you know, a hook, like that guy on the subway who eats his own face. So I figure I'll be Crazy Man with a Snake, y=know. Crazy Snake Man. And I'll get more snakes, call them my babies, kids will walk past my place, they will run. "Run away from Crazy Snake Man," they'll shout!
MONICA: You have got to get over this. You're not gonna end up alone.
CHANDLER: Of course I am. I reject anyone who's crazy enough to actually go out with me, and then I bitch about the fact that there aren't any great women out there.
RACHEL: Chandler, you have just described virtually every man that we have ever gone out with.
MONICA: You are not a freak. You're a guy.
RACHEL: She's right. She's right. You are no different than the rest of them.
MONICA: Wait a minute, wait a minute. Yes he is. You are totally different.
CHANDLER: In a bad way?
MONICA: No, honey, in a wonderful way. You know what you want now. Most guys don't even have a clue. You are ready to take risks, you are ready to be vulnerable, and intimate with someone.
RACHEL: Yeah. You're not gonna end up alone.
PHOEBE: Chandler, you called Janice! That's how much you wanted to be with someone!
MONICA: You made it!
PHOEBE: You're there!
RACHEL: You are ready to make a commitment!
CHANDLER: Whoa! Don't know about that.
RACHEL: What you got there? Something else that's not yours that you can break?
MONICA: No. Um, I know you like this, and I want you to have it. I think it'll look good in our apartment.
RACHEL: Thank you.
MONICA: That's fine.
CHANDLER: Hey. Well, you will all be pleased to know that I have a date tomorrow night. This woman, Alison, from work. She's great. She's pretty, she's smart. And uh, I've been holding off on asking her out in the past, because she has an unusually large head. But, I'm not gonna let that stuff hang me up anymore. Look at me. I'm growing.
JOEY: Hey, uh, you can't recycle yearbooks, can you?
CHANDLER: I'll take that.
JOEY: You want his yearbook?
CHANDLER: Yeah, yeah. Some people said some nice things about him. I think somebody should have it.
MONICA: Oh, gosh, this is so weird. I mean, his whole life was in this apartment, and now it's gone. You know, I think it would be nice if we just took a few moments, for Mr. Heckles. I mean, he was kind of a pain, he was, but, he was a person. You're all going to hell.
RACHEL: It's really not that big!
CHANDLER: Takin' that with you, huh?
JOEY: Oh, yeah.
ROSS: You comin'?
CHANDLER: Yeah, jus' second. Good-bye Mr. Heckles. We'll try to keep it down.
ALISON: Oh, my major was totally useless. I mean, how often do you look in the classifieds and see "Philosopher wanted"?
CHANDLER: Sure. (My god, that's a big head! It didn't look this big in the office. Maybe it's the lighting. My head must look like a golf ball at work. All right, don't get hung up on it, quick, quick, list five things you like about her: Nice smile, good dresser...Big head, big head, big head!)
END

(knock)

MR. HECKLES: I could have birds.

lines.speaker: MONICA

MR. HECKLES: Thank you. I'm going to rejoin my dinner party.

lines.speaker: RACHEL

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Ok, Janice. Janice. You gotta give me Janice. That wasn't about being picky.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: We'll give you Janice.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: I miss Janice though. "Hello, Chandler Bing."

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: "Oh, my, god."

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: "Oh, Chandler, now, now, that's it. There, faster!"

lines.speaker: MONICA

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: We won. We won!

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Mr. Heckles.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: How did this happen?
MR. TREEGER: He musta been sweepin'. They found a broom in his hand.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: That's terrible.
MR. TREEGER: I know. I was sweepin' yesterday. It coulda been me.ROSS: Sure, sweepin'. You never know.
MR. TREEGER: You never know.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Ok, it's very faint, but I can still sense him in the building. Go into the light, Mr. Heckles!

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Ok, Phoebe.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: I'm sorry, but sometimes they need help. That's fine. Go ahead and scoff. You know, there're a lot of things that I don't believe in, but that doesn't mean they're not true.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Such as?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Like crop circles, or the Bermuda triangle, or evolution?

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. What, you don't, uh, you don't believe in evolution?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Nah. Not really.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: You don't believe in evolution?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Too easy? Too...The process of every living thing on this planet evolving over millions of years from single-celled organisms, too easy?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Yeah, I just don't buy it.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Uh, excuse me. Evolution is not for you to buy, Phoebe. Evolution is scientific fact, like, like, like the air we breathe, like gravity.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Ok, don't get me started on gravity.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: You uh, you don't believe in gravity?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Well, it's not so much that you know, like I don't believe in it, you know, it's just...I don't know, lately I get the feeling that I'm not so much being pulled down as I am being pushed.
(knock)

lines.speaker: CHANDLER

MR. TREEGER: There she is. And over there, that's the other one. This is Mr. Buddy Boyle, Mr. Heckles' attorney. He'd like to talk to you.

lines.speaker: MONICA

MR. BOYLE: All right, kids. Here's the deal. According to my client's will, he wants to leave all his earthly possessions to "the noisy girls in the apartment above mine".

lines.speaker: MONICA

MR. BOYLE: He didn't have any.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Ok, so let's talk money.
MR. BOYLE: All right, there was none. Let's talk signing. You be noisy girl number one, you be noisy girl number two.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: I can't believe that this whole time we thought he hated us. I mean, isn't it amazing how much you can touch someone's life, without even knowing it?...Would you look at this dump? He hated us. This is his final revenge!

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Have you ever seen so much crap?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Actually, I think this apartment sullies the good name of crap

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Check this out. Can I have this?

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: How can you not believe in evolution?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Just don't. Look at this funky shirt!

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Pheebs, I have studied evolution my entire adult life. Ok, I can tell you, we have collected fossils from all over the world that actually show the evolution of different species, ok? You can literally see them evolving through time.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Really? You can actually see it?

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: You bet. In the U.S., China, Africa, all over.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: See, I didn't know that.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Well, there you go.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Huh. So now, the real question is, who put those fossils there, and why?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Hey, look at this. "My Big Book of Grievances."

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Hey, there's me! April 17th. Excessive noise. Italian guy comes homes with a date. Hey Chandler, look, you're in here too.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: April 18th, excessive noise. Italian guy's gay roommate comes home with the dry-cleaning. Well that's excellent.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Monica, Monica, look at this lamp. Is this tacky or what? We have to have this.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Rache, I think we have enough regular lamps.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: What? Come on, it's not like I'm asking for this girly clock or anything, which, by the way, I also think is very cool.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: It doesn't go with any of my stuff.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Well, what about my stuff?

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: You don't have any stuff.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: You still think of it as your apartment, don't you?

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Yes you do. You think of it as your apartment, and I'm just somebody who rents a room.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Mmmmm.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Ok, while you "mmm" on it for awhile, I'm gonna go find a place for my new lamp.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Ok, Pheebs. See how I'm making these little toys move? Opposable thumbs. Without evolution, how do you explain opposable thumbs?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Maybe the overlords needed them to steer their spacecrafts.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Please tell me you're joking.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Look, can't we just say that you believe in something, and I don't.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: No, no, Pheebs, we can't, ok, because--

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: What is this obsessive need you have to make everyone agree with you? No, what's that all about? I think, I think maybe it's time you put Ross under the microscope.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Is there blood coming out of my ears?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Check it out, check it out. Heckles' high school yearbook.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Wow, he looks so normal.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: He's even kind of cute.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: "Heckles, you crack me up in science class. You're the funniest kid in school.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Funniest? Heckles?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: That's what it says.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Wow, Heckles was voted class clown, and so was I. He was right. Would you listen to that?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: I'd call that excessive.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Whoa!

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Heckles played clarinet in band, and I played clarinet. And he was in the scale modeler's club, and I was, well, there was no club, but I sure thought they were cool.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: So, you were both dorks. Big deal.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: I just think it's weird, you know? Heckles and me, Heckles, and me, me and Heckles...Would you knock it off?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Have you been here all night?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Look at this. Pictures of all the women that Heckles went out with. Look what he wrote on them. Vivian, too tall. Madge, big gums. Too loud, too smart, makes noise when she eats. This is, this is me. This is what I do. I'm gonna end up alone, just like he did.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Chandler, Heckles was a nut case.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Our trains are on the same track, ok? Yeah, sure, I'm coming up 30 years behind him, but the stops are all the same. Bitter Town. Aloneville. Hermit Junction.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: All right, you know what we gotta do? We gotta get you outta here. Come on, I'll buy you breakfast, let's go.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: What if I never find someone? Or worse, what if I've found her, but I dumped her because she pronounced it "supposably"?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Chandler, come on, you're gonna find somebody.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: How do you know that? How?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: I don't know, I'm just tryin' to help you out.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: You'll see, you guys are all gonna go off and get married, and I'm gonna end up alone. Will you promise me something? When you're married, will you invite me over for holidays?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Well, I don't know. I don't know what we're gonna be doin'. I mean, what if we're at her folks' place?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Yeah, I understand.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: You can come over and watch the Super Bowl. Every year, all right?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: You know what? I'm not gonna end up like this. I'll see you man.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Supposably. Supposably. Did they go to the zoo? Supposably.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: (on phone) Hi, it's me.

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: Oh, my, god.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Janice? You called Janice?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Yes, Janice. Why is that so difficult for you to comprehend?

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: You remember Janice, right?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Yes. She was smart, she was pretty, and she honestly cared about me. Janice is my last chance to have somebody.

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: Helloo!!

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Oh, my, god!

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Geez, look how fat she got.

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: Hey, it's everybody.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Janice, you're--

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: Yes, I am.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Is it--?

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: Is it yours? Ha! You wish, Chandler Bing. You are looking at a married lady now.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Congratulations.

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: Oh, sweetie, I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: You couldn't have told me about this on the phone?

lines.speaker: JANICE
lines.text: And what? Missed the expression on your face? Janice likes to have her fun.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Hey, Rache. You know what we haven't played in a while?

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Hide the Lamp.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Monica, let it go.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Did you know I was allergic to shellfish?

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Well, then, you'll just have to eat the other lamps.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Uh-oh. It's Scary Scientist Man.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: Ok, Phoebe, this is it. In this briefcase I carry actual scientific facts. A briefcase of facts, if you will. Some of these fossils are over 200 million years old.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Ok, look, before you even start, I'm not denying evolution, ok, I'm just saying that it's one of the possibilities.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: It's the only possibility, Phoebe.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Ok, Ross, could you just open your mind like this much, ok? Wasn't there a time when the brightest minds in the world believed that the world was flat? And, up until like what, 50 years ago, you all thought the atom was the smallest thing, until you split it open, and this like, whole mess of crap came out. Now, are you telling me that you are so unbelievably arrogant that you can't admit that there's a teeny tiny possibility that you could be wrong about this?

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: There might be, a teeny, tiny, possibility.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: I can't believe you caved.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: You just abandoned your whole belief system. I mean, before, I didn't agree with you, but at least I respected you. How, how, how are you going to go into work tomorrow? How, how are you going to face the other science guys? How, how are you going to face yourself? Oh! That was fun. So who's hungry?

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: I am. Let me just get my coat.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Ok, all right. It was an accident, I swear, all right. I was putting on my jacket, and the thing, and the lamp, and it broke.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Oh, please, Monica. You've always hated my lamp, and then, all of a sudden, it's just magically broken?

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Phoebe, tell her!

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Ok, I didn't see it, because I was putting on my jacket, but I uh want to believe you.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Hey Chandler. Monica just broke my seashell lamp.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Neat. I'm gonna die alone.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Ok, you win.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Chandler, you're not gonna die alone.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Janice was my safety net, ok? And now I have to get a snake.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Uh huh. Why is that?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: If I'm gonna be an old, lonely man, I'm gonna need a thing, you know, a hook, like that guy on the subway who eats his own face. So I figure I'll be Crazy Man with a Snake, y=know. Crazy Snake Man. And I'll get more snakes, call them my babies, kids will walk past my place, they will run. "Run away from Crazy Snake Man," they'll shout!

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: You have got to get over this. You're not gonna end up alone.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Of course I am. I reject anyone who's crazy enough to actually go out with me, and then I bitch about the fact that there aren't any great women out there.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Chandler, you have just described virtually every man that we have ever gone out with.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: You are not a freak. You're a guy.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: She's right. She's right. You are no different than the rest of them.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Wait a minute, wait a minute. Yes he is. You are totally different.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: In a bad way?

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: No, honey, in a wonderful way. You know what you want now. Most guys don't even have a clue. You are ready to take risks, you are ready to be vulnerable, and intimate with someone.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Yeah. You're not gonna end up alone.

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: Chandler, you called Janice! That's how much you wanted to be with someone!

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: You made it!

lines.speaker: PHOEBE
lines.text: You're there!

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: You are ready to make a commitment!

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Whoa! Don't know about that.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: What you got there? Something else that's not yours that you can break?

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: No. Um, I know you like this, and I want you to have it. I think it'll look good in our apartment.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: That's fine.

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Hey. Well, you will all be pleased to know that I have a date tomorrow night. This woman, Alison, from work. She's great. She's pretty, she's smart. And uh, I've been holding off on asking her out in the past, because she has an unusually large head. But, I'm not gonna let that stuff hang me up anymore. Look at me. I'm growing.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Hey, uh, you can't recycle yearbooks, can you?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: I'll take that.

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: You want his yearbook?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Yeah, yeah. Some people said some nice things about him. I think somebody should have it.

lines.speaker: MONICA
lines.text: Oh, gosh, this is so weird. I mean, his whole life was in this apartment, and now it's gone. You know, I think it would be nice if we just took a few moments, for Mr. Heckles. I mean, he was kind of a pain, he was, but, he was a person. You're all going to hell.

lines.speaker: RACHEL
lines.text: It's really not that big!

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Takin' that with you, huh?

lines.speaker: JOEY
lines.text: Oh, yeah.

lines.speaker: ROSS
lines.text: You comin'?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Yeah, jus' second. Good-bye Mr. Heckles. We'll try to keep it down.

lines.speaker: ALISON
lines.text: Oh, my major was totally useless. I mean, how often do you look in the classifieds and see "Philosopher wanted"?

lines.speaker: CHANDLER
lines.text: Sure. (My god, that's a big head! It didn't look this big in the office. Maybe it's the lighting. My head must look like a golf ball at work. All right, don't get hung up on it, quick, quick, list five things you like about her: Nice smile, good dresser...Big head, big head, big head!)
END
